result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: The CO supported 10 youth friendly corners with equipment to encourage the use of these corners in health facilities where young people including adolescents have access to basic health services and can also be referred if needs be. Peer educators were also trained by some of our IPs to ensure that young people have the right information to pass on to their peers to enable them make informed decisions. The CO also used the celebration of international days such as the World Population Day as an entry point to provide age appropriate and targeted information, and linkages to SRH services with the aim to reducing teenage pregnancy. The CO also supported the National Youth Authority to deploy mobile technology to facilitate transmission of youth targeted messages on sexuality education

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: With CO support, 30 implementing partners improved their knowledge on UNFPAs strategy for adolescents and youth at strategic planning meetings. The National Youth Authority has developed a manual on ASRH and related issues for their youth coordinators who work at the district level with CO support. The manual will serve as both a reference and working document for accurate ASRH information to meet the needs of marginalized youth. In addition, the CO supported the initiation of a mapping of youth- led organizations in the country. The mapping will completely document information on who is working where in relation to both youth-focused and youth-led organisations. The mapping exercise when completed, will build synergies in the delivery of ASRH and related services to young people. As a means of facilitating evidence based design and programming for marginalized and adolescent girls, the CO continued support for the conduct of a comprehensive situational analysis on young people. The CO, in partnership with government and the UN Country Team, has identified and recruited a research institution to undertake the assignment. The CO has ensured that as part of the literature review, which is the first deliverable, has reflected issues such as teenage pregnancy, unsafe abortion, early marriages and youth participation, among others

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: The CO supported the National Population council to begin the process to review the current Adolescent Sexual Health Policy which was formulated in 2000 to make it more relevant to issues and priorities that have emerged since. The policy will guide strategic programming on rights based adolescent health and development issues in the country. The CO in partnership with UNICEF and UNESCO also supported the review of the HIV Alert Model and this will now reflect comprehensive life skills based sexuality education issues. The school based curriculum that incorporates age-appropriate sexuality education is being rolled out by the Curriculum Development Division of the Ghana Education Service (GES). During the period under review, the CO supported advocacy sessions conducted by the GES with district directors of education to gain support and ownership of the programme. Roll out of the use of the curriculum was also initiated in 14 out of the 30 UNFPA supported districts.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core family planning activities
result.description: UNFPA CO contributed by providing technical support through participation in quarterly meetings of the inter-agency coordination committee on Commodity Security (ICC/CS)with government, and development partners and donors. This committee provides a platform for coordination and discussion on: Contraceptive planning and forecasting and procurement:. At these meetings, consumption patterns for the various commodities are reviewed against the contraceptive stock levels and the estimated dates of arrival of procurement orders. Contraceptive Procurement: UNFPA CO procured contraceptives including mainly condoms, norigynon, depo provera and other RH commodities including oxytocin to augment contraceptive levels to prevent stock-outs. UNFPA has procured a vehicle for the Ghana Health Service at the national level, to support field level monitoring especially consumption patterns and forecasting of contraceptive at the facility level. In spite of these interventions, there still exist some bottle necks in the supply chain system. UNFPA and other development partners provided technical support to the Ministry of Health to develop a new yet-to-be approved costed supply chain management plan. UNFPA is advocating for public/private sector partnership to address the supply chain challenges. Discussions have been initiated with Coca Cola to support in this direction.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core family planning activities
result.description: The CO provided financial support for the training of 60 service providers (SPs) drawn from facilities across remote and hard to reach districts in implanon/jadelle insertion and removal to increase the number of SPs to meet the slow but increasing demand for long-term FP methods. Additionally, financial support was provided to enable over 40 Community Health Nurses to be trained in family planning counselling with emphasis on long-term methods to improve upon family planning coverage in the districts.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core family planning activities
result.description: The CO provided financial and technical support for the national launch of the Family Planning Week celebration in the Volta Region (Ho) on 2nd September 2013, under the theme: Your Future, your choice, your contraception: Act Now. The choice of this region for the national launch was informed by the fact that the region has the highest unmet need for family planning of 37.9%. ( Source: MICS 2011).

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core family planning activities
result.description: Through the sustained advocacy efforts of the CO and other development partners over the years, the Government has given approval for cost of family planning services, especially the long-term methods to be covered under the National Health Insurance scheme. When the directive is operationalized, it will result in the removal of financial barriers to assessing family planning services, especially for the rural poor.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core family planning activities
result.description: Through the technical and financial support as well as the advocacy efforts, it has resulted in the following: - Only 35% of SDPs experienced stock-outs throughout the year - The inclusion of the costs for the provision of long-term family planning methods into the National Health Insurance Scheme - The commitment from the President of Ghana to track the CARMMA implementation of pledges made by Metropolitan and District Assemblies towards improving maternal and new-born care services. Some challenges yet to be addressed are:(i)Weaknesses in contraceptive forecasting due to inadequate data processing capability and poor management of inventory. (ii). Low uptake and utilization of family planning services due to shortage of contraceptives at some SDPs (poor inventory management challenges) and some gender and socio-cultural factors.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core family planning activities
result.description: CARMMA Launch and Accountability Framework: The CO in collaboration with the former first lady (2009-2012), launched the Campaign for the accelerated Reduction in Maternal Mortality in Africa (CARMMA) in Ghana and across all 10 regions of the country. At the regional launches, all local level political leaders (Metropolitan and District Assemblies) made pledges, stating in concrete terms what they are going to do in their localities to promote maternal and newborn care services towards reducing maternal and newborn morbidity and mortality. The immediate results were: The commitment of additional resources for maternal and newborn care services at national, regional and local levels; and development of an accountability tool to assess the performance of the entire metropolitan and district assemblies as all pledges and commitments made were captured and compiled into a booklet. On 30th November 2013 the booklet on CARMMA reports from the 10 regions was launched by the President. Minsters of State from the 10 regions, presented reports on the status of implementation of the pledges made to the former First Lady. The President stressed that the status maternal and newborn cares services will be a key indicator for assessing the performance of the local government leadership and tasked the Regional Ministers to organize forums at the regional levels and present the reports of the tracking of the implementation of CARMMA pledges to the people. This advocacy efforts is replicable as the steps followed are clearly documented:. Identify a champions and provide them with information for their commitment ii. Document all pledges made by political/traditional leaders iii. Ensure that the pledge made are precise, measurable with timelines iv. Follow-up, document and publicize the implementation of the pledges, using a system of peer review.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core data availability and analysis activities
result.description: As the lead agency in the UN System in Ghana for censuses and related surveys (on population dynamics), the Country Office continued to coordinate the production, launch and dissemination of Monographs from the 2010 Census. Through the leadership and advocacy of the Country Office, five thematic monographs (Non-monetary Poverty, Millennium Development Goals, Women and Men in Ghana, Children, Adolescents and Young People in Ghana, and The Elderly in Ghana) were completed in 2012 with UN system, including Country Office support, have been printed, launched and disseminated. The final drafts of additional eight thematic monographs started in 2013 have been completed (which would be printed, launched and disseminated in 2014). Other development partners; CIDA, DANIDA and JICA also supported the development of Regional Reports (CIDA) and District Reports (DANIDA and JICA).

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core data availability and analysis activities
result.description: As a step towards creating awareness and building data analysis capacity of the relevant institutions towards evidence based development discourse, the Country Office supported staff of Ghana Statistical Service to train some of their staff under seasoned consultant writers during the development of the census monographs. In order to build capacity for policy formulation and programming decision making, the Country Office in collaboration with Agence Francaise de Developpement (AFD) supported a National Dialogue on Harnessing Ghana's Demographic Dividend, The initiative was jointly organized by the National Development Planning Commission (NDPC), National Population Council (NPC) the Regional Institute for Population Studies (RIPS) and the Institute for Statistical, Social and Economic Research (ISSER) both at the University of Ghana. The four-day National Dialogue comprised a seminar, four follow-up workshops and a round table discussion. The demographic dividend seminar and workshops were preceded by a training session for selected media houses on the analysis and appreciation of demographic statistics. This intervention was designed to enable media personnel understand the National Dialogue on Harnessing the National Demographic Dividend and sharpen their reportage of the issues raised. Factors that facilitated this achievement firstly, was the ownership and leadership shown by the National Development Planning Commission in the quest to make Harnessing Ghana's Demographic Agenda one of the key policy objectives of the new medium term development framework (2014-2017). Ready support (financial and technical) from both UNFPA and AFD Country and Regional Offices was also a critical fillip to the achievement of this result.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core data availability and analysis activities
result.description: The leadership provided by the Country Office has been a key contributor to the achievement of results under this outcome. The bi-monthly meetings hosted by the Country office provided regular updates to all development partners on the status of report development processes such that financial support for the development/printing of monographs were ring-fenced even during budget reviews

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core data availability and analysis activities
result.description: Conference report writing proved to be a good practice in the development of census and survey reports. As noted earlier, the National Statistics Bureau of South Sudan have indicated strongly their decision to adopt this practice.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: The CO provided TA (briefing notes and key messages on UNFPA mandate and interest issues) to the Hon. Minister of Gender, Children and Social Protection, (MoGCSP) and the Ghana delegation to the 2013 CSW. The CO is also providing financial support for the printing and dissemination of the country report of the 2013 CSW conference. Financial and technical support was also provided by the CO for the development of concept note and TOR for the engagement of the consultant for the revision of the national gender policy, (NGP) , to reflect the new mandate of the Ministry of Gender, Children and Social Protection [MoGCSP] as well as inclusion of issues on social protection

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: The country office in the year under review provided TA and financial support to the Domestic Violence and Victim Support Unit, DOVVSU, of the Ghana Police Service to develop manual on GBV for the training of police personnel in Ghana. The CO also supported the unit to develop and print IE&C materials on GBV/DV for dissemination as part of its outreach programmes. Financial support was provided to the Ministry of Gender for the celebration of the 2013 16 days of Activism on domestic violence. TA was also provided for development of the concept note and TOR for the engagement of consultant to support the establishment and training of districts DV steering committee in the UNFPA programme districts in 2014. This is expected to facilitate the implementation of the DV law and monitoring of local capacity and responses as well as progress.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: The CO in 2013 supported the International Federation of Female Lawyers (FIDA-Ghana) with re-training of District community paralegals on the effective ways of engaging men and boys at the community level on gender equality, ASRH, Rights and GBV. The CO provided financial support to the Department of Women under the Ministry of Gender, Children and social protection to organise media engagement with traditional leaders and media personnel on men and boys involvement in gender equality, GBV, SRH and ASRH. The session build the skills of the personnel on how best to sensitise community members on the general benefits of men ensuring SRH, FP and FP, and supporting gender equality, the rights of women and girls and prevention of GBV.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core gender equality and reproductive rights activities
result.description: -CO provided support for the review of the national gender policy (NGP) to reflect the ministrys new mandate which now includes social protection and the completion of the legislative instrument on the implementation of the domestic violence law. The support provided comprised both technical and financial components.

conditions.condition: The United Nations issues a criticality level for specific activities implemented within a given geographic location and timeframe. This Programme Criticality level determination would then be used in the Acceptable Risk Model to ensure that UN personnel do not take unnecessary risk and that those who remain in-country work on highest priority activities in accordance with UN strategic results.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: HIV and SRH integration is part of a routine process in Ghana. The CO continues to support the strengthening of linkages at the both policy and systems levels. At the systems level, thirty (30) PLHIV leaders with representation from PLHIV networks in all 10 regions of Ghana enhanced their knowledge on SRH and HIV integration and rights based programming. As a means to strengthen Prong 2 of PMTCT, special emphasis was laid on the role and responsibilities of PLHIV on the prevention of abortion and unintended pregnancies. The PLHIV are expected to boost their critical role as community actors in facilitating collaboration mechanisms between HIV and SRH programmes at community level. A key constraint is the non-availability of specific national data collection tools on PMTCT Prong 2. In response to the low access to PEP services, 100 police personnel from the Domestic Violence and Victim Support Unit (DOVVSU) and the Community Policing Unit (CPU) of the Ghana Police Service were empowered to avail survivors of sexual violence with PEP services. The police personnel with representation from 3 UNFPA target regions are expected to facilitate early and timely referrals of sexually abused persons including female sex workers for PEP services, specifically counselling, emergency contraception, testing and prevention of HIV. The COs technical support for the revised national HIV and STI policy facilitated the inclusion of key elements of HIV and SRH integration in the national HIV and AIDS response. The policy has been disseminated and provides guidance on e-MTCT, HTC, and condom use among others, with underpinning human rights, legal and ethical issues. The CO also provided technical inputs on HIV and SRH integration for inclusion in the national gender and social protection policy currently under revision.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The CO supported Ghana AIDS Commission (GAC) to disseminate the Joint Youth Action Matrix (JYAM), a national reference point for HIV programming among young people. A national youth forum was also organized by GAC with support from the CO for 120 stakeholders, including young people with representation from all 10 regions of Ghana. With the COs technical input, the forum discussed the progress made on the JYAM, agreed on immediate priorities and strengthened GACs linkages with youth led and youth serving organizations. A significant output of the forum was the establishment of a five member team with representation from the youth to coordinate the implementation of the JYAM. In view of the dwindling donor funding availability for youth activities, the GAC has earmarked GOG funds to support youth-led organizations to implement key activities under the JYAM in 2014. As a means to reaching young vulnerable populations with rights based integrated HIV prevention and SRH information and services, 30 female head porters (Kayaye) from 5 markets and 20 refugees from four camps were empowered as community based mobilisers and peer educators respectively. The empowered youth have facilitated access to and enhanced knowledge of about 3,000 kayaye and refugees on integrated HIV prevention and SRH issues at their respective areas of jurisdiction. The CO engaged 20 female sex workers, including adolescents aged between 16 and 19 years in strategic planning for FSW programming in selected UNFPA target districts. The approach served as an entry point for greater involvement and leadership of FSW in programme design and implementation on HIV/SRH integration and violence reduction. The FSW and selected youth advocates were also equipped with advocacy skills and engaged in round table discussions with senior level police personnel to improve partnerships in reducing stigma, GBV and harassment from police personnel.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The CO, through participation in the Technical Working Group for on key populations is contributing to the development of a package of standard operating procedures (SOP) for use by key populations this group. The SOPs, upon completion will facilitate access to comprehensive HIV services by key populations. In addition, the CO provided technical inputs into the development of a stigma and discrimination tracking system for PLHIV and key populations. The tracking system has been launched and is managed by the Commission of Human Rights and Administrative Justice (CHRAJ). The tracking system will seek to track discrimination cases and facilitate redress to promote human rights and non-discriminatory access to comprehensive HIV and STI prevention services, among others.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The National HIV and AIDS Strategic Plan (2011-2015) highlight elements of the comprehensive condom programming approach. The CO is supporting the National Population Council, the Ghana AIDS Commission, the Ghana Health Service and other relevant partners to develop a comprehensive costed condom strategy. The strategy will aim at decreasing the incidence and spread of HIV/STI and unplanned pregnancies and seek to establish mechanisms for coordination and monitoring of a sustainable system that includes demand, supply, supporting environment (policy, regulations), advocacy, training and evaluation in a country in which government, donors, and the private sector. The CO supported GAC to organize an innovative condom promotion campaign at the national HIV and AIDS research conference. The campaign created a platform for over 500 participants at the conference to improve knowledge, innovative condom social marketing approaches to create demand and reduce HIV transmission. Notwithstanding the COs support for the re-launch of the female condom, the patronage continues to be low. The country experienced condom stock out during the year in view of the retrieval of 128 million pieces of low quality Be Safe condoms imported into the country; thus raising key procurement concerns that need to be addressed.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked hiv and sexually transmitted infection prevention services activities
result.description: The COs support for policy development and HIV prevention interventions contributed to the reduced HIV prevalence among the general population. The findings of the mid-term review of the National HIV and AIDS Strategic Plan (NSP 2011-2015), conducted with support from the CO, indicates the significant attention to HIV prevention has contributed to reducing the number of new HIV infection from 12,077 in 2011 to 7,991 in 2012. The HIV prevalence also reduced from 1.5% in 2010 and 2011 respectively to 1.37% in 2012 in the general population. The HIV antenatal prevalence among young people aged 15-24 years reduced from 1.7% in 2011 to 1.3% in 2012. The mid term evaluation findings also indicate number of male condoms distributed among key populations increased by 30.1% from 4,413,404 in 2011 to 5,741,354 in 2012. Assuming there is no growth in the estimated size of sex workers, the number of sex workers reached increased from 49.0 in 2011 to 73.6% in 2012. Considering the rate of increase the target of 80% by 2015 as indicated in the NSP can be reached. This, it is hoped will reduce the HIV prevalence among FSW which currently stands at 11.1%.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core population dynamics activities
result.description: The CO successfully advocated for and provided Technical assistance for the inclusion of reproductive health response into the National Relief and Reconstruction Management Plan of the National Disaster Management Organization in Ghana. Printing of copies of this document was supported by the CO in 2013.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core population dynamics activities
result.description: The country office in collaboration with Agence Francaise de Dveloppement (AFD) supported a four-day national dialogue on How to Capitalize on Ghanas Demographic Dividend for Accelerated Development which was jointly organized by the National Development Planning Commission (NDPC), the National Population Council (NPC), and the Academia (University of Ghana, ISSER and RIPS) from 24-27 September 2013. The National Development Planning Commission (NDPC), finding the conclusions and recommendations of the study report as relevant input for the successor of the Ghana Shared Growth and Development Agenda (GSGDA) 2014-2017 under review, sought therefore to dialogue with the four key sectors; education, health, economic and governance. The objectives of the dialogue were to introduce the concept of demographic dividend, explain the role each sector can play in harnessing the demographic dividend for accelerated development and for each of the sectors to reflect necessary the programme activities aimed at harnessing the demographic dividend in their respective sector policy matrices of the new 2014-17 GSGDA

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core population dynamics activities
result.description: The CO provided Technical Assistance to government in the discussions leading to revision of the national RH policy and standards and provided inputs to ensure that Obstetric fistula is captured as part of the revised document. Hitherto obstetrics fistula has been excluded from the document. The technical argument and data provided by the CO during the deliberations ended up convincing stakeholders who unanimously agreed to the inclusion of obstetric Fistula in the pending revision. Preparatory work for the final revision is ongoing and the CO will continue to provide the much needed support to ensure this is accomplished.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core population dynamics activities
result.description: New members of the Youth Advisory Panel were competitively selected from the target regions of the programme and given training on the mandate the strategic plan, programme focus, programme implementation modalities and their role.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana core population dynamics activities
result.description: The synergy resulting from the CO strategy of collaborating with UN-System Agencies as well as other development partners to develop and implement medium term interventions with the respective government agencies facilitated the achievement of this outcome; - the 2010 census was successfully taken on time - census results and thematic, region and district monograph have been developed and released timely (UNFPA, UNDP, WHO, IOM, UNHCR, UKAID, EU, CIDA, DANIDA etc) - for the first time in the history of the country a national dialogue was organized on harnessing the National demographic dividend for accelerated national development (AFD, UNFPA, NDPC, NPC and Academia) - the National RH policy was successfully revised to include Fistula as an important program (UNFPA,MOH,USAID, GHS, WFP) - Reproductive health was included in the National Relief and Reconstruction Management Plan as response area in the National Disaster management organization in Ghana (UNFPA, UNICEF, NADMO, MOH, GHS, UNHCR, IOM etc) - births and deaths records were digitized and made accessible for inclusion in the national Civil Registration and vital statistics system being developed (UNFPA, UNICEF, UNECA, AfDB, AUC, BDR(Gh), etc..

conditions.condition: The United Nations issues a criticality level for specific activities implemented within a given geographic location and timeframe. This Programme Criticality level determination would then be used in the Acceptable Risk Model to ensure that UN personnel do not take unnecessary risk and that those who remain in-country work on highest priority activities in accordance with UN strategic results.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: The CO in collaboration with WHO office provided technical support to the Nurses and Midwives Council for the review of the curriculum for midwifery training schools which is underway. In addition the CO supplied/procured mannequins and equipment for student learning procured for Midwifery Training Institutes in Ghana. All Equipment and mannequins were handed over to the MoH in an official ceremony on 28 Oct 2013. In the area of e-learning, an e-learning platform for midwives was initiated: 4 modules developed, stakeholder meeting done. Training was postponed to first undertake assessment of skills laboratory and IT laboratories in 23 training schools. Further Technical and financial support to Diploma Midwifery curriculum review to be used from next academic year. This review was completed at the KNUST (Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology in Kumasi) and MoH announced that another BSc will be established at University of Development Studies-Midwifery School in Tamale. These 2 new programmes in five years will receive support through UNFPA Midwifery Programme/MHTF). The challenge is the limitation posed by the division between the two midwifery associations in Ghana which impacts on programmes which require joint collaboration or participation of all midwives. Furthermore, the delay in completing the skills laboratory and IT surveys has slowed down the e-Learning programme. UNFPA is collaborating with JHPIEGO to redress this in 2014.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: As a follow up to the findings of the EmONC needs assessment of 2010 and the need to fill gaps identified in the survey and in relation to MAF, the CO in 2013 provided 35 blood bank fridges, five anaesthetic machines , and assorted medical and surgical equipment including Cesarean section kits and, delivery kits that enhance EmONC delivery. In addition the CO continued to engage in dialogue with other stakeholders such as government, USAID and UNICEF to encourage government to commit to filling gaps identified in EmONC needs assessment. UNFPA represents the UN agencies on the MAF National Steering Committee where it provides technical and policy guide for implementation of MAF including EmONC. The CO regularly updates the UNCT and encourages relevant agencies to support the MAF implementation. A mechanism exists to report to the CEB on quarterly basis and UNFPA has been designated by the RCO as the lead agency for consolidating the CEB quarterly report.. The MAF plan to procure equipment and vehicles for national distribution faces slow progress because of national laws and bureaucratic process needed. This naturally has effect on the efficiency of UNFPA support which is expected to fill a gap.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: Obstetric fistula care prevention and treatment, rehabilitation and reintegration of repaired patients remain high on UNFPA agenda. In 2013 eighty-one (81) clients had successful fistula repairs and 48 previously repaired patients underwent a two-week skills training in batik tie and dye making, soap and pomade making and confectionery to enable them properly integrate into their respective communities and be productive. Economic empowerment of repaired fistula clients has in the past proven to be very beneficial to them, their family and the communities they emanate from. UNFPA has also resourced the National Fistula Centre with equipment, fistula kits 1&2, assorted consumables and commodity. With the support of the US-based philanthropic foundation Friends of UNFPA, an anaesthetic machine and a 400L capacity autoclave is being procured for the Centre. In addition, resources from the programmegroup have been earmarked for the training of three Doctors and three Nurses of the Ghana Health service to expand available teams for fistula surgery. This training faced some challenges because the institute in Nigeria which facilitates the training would only be ready to do that in 2014. Efforts to engage a fistula training institute in Addis for the same purpose did not yield the needed results. This year, very little programme inputs was done by way of prevention. The CO has been hindered by procedures and conditions required to engage credible implementing and sub-implementing partners to undertake advocacy and BSCC efforts. The need for establishing a national fistula task force to develop and implement a national fistula strategy persists with key stakeholders in the country.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: CO has supported implementation of MISP through the prepositioning and provision of emergency reproductive health kits as part of its core programmes. To further strengthen national capacity to implement the MISP by international standards, UNFPA Ghana built the capacity of 19 RH coordinators from Government Agencies, NGOs and other humanitarian actors in MISP for RH in Crisis. UNFPA CO intends to continue the trainings to build capacities of service providers on the MISP in all regions of Ghana. The CO successfully advocated for the inclusion of reproductive health response in the National Relief and Reconstruction Management Plan for Disaster Response.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: UNFPA CO has been very active in engaging government and other stakeholders to ensure effective delivery of this outcome. It has supported skilled delivery and EmONC through TA and financial assistance to pre-service and in-service human resource capacity development and provision of equipment to support EmONC. Thus through its advocacy and technical support to Ghanas Life-Saving Skills (LSS) capacity development programme for in-service providers and its midwifery program to ensure effective teaching and learning in school. UNFPA has built capacity to contribute to improvement in indicators for maternal and child health. The MMR is now 350/100,000LB (UN System Estimate -by the Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-agency Group: MMEIG) down from 740/100,000LB in 1990 though at the current pace the possibility of reaching the national target for MMR of 185/100,000LB by 2015 is remote. The CPR is now 23.6% (MICS 2011) as against 17% (DHS 2008). Supervised delivery is 68% (GHS report 2012) as against 60% (DHS 2008). Currently, Ghanas unmet need for FP now stands at 26.4% (MICS 2011) compared to 35.7% in 2008 (DHS). The U5MR is now 80/1000 (DHS 2008) compared with 111/1000 (DHS 2003) Though there seems to be a favourable trend in the MNHC indicators; this is only so because many years of stagnation and slow decline, as indicated above. Tthe need to intensify activities efforts and scale up cost effective interventions cannot be over emphasized. At the current rate, MMR could only drop to 340/100,000LB by 2015 thus missing the MDG5 target. To further strengthen supervision and ensure efficient work the CO will continue to consolidate not only the efforts in advocacy and capacity development, but also the provision of quality service delivery at the subnational levels. In that respect in the field this year the CO provided equipment and logistics including 5 Toyota Hilux pick up vehicles for strengthening monitoring.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked maternal and newborn health activities
result.description: The CO methodology and approach to engaging its stakeholders and implementing partners at all levels (national, regional and district) is a practice worthy of emulation. The planning process involves national partners and regional as well as district implementing partners. This broad consultation and involvement is suitable for wider ownership of the AWP interventions and strategies. This approach is novel and a trailblazer in guiding the government and especially the local authorities [regional coordinating councils and district assemblies] to appreciate implementation of the decentralisation policy of government. The challenge is that the process is naturally slow and relatively expensive initially but potentially cost saving in the end.

This Programme Criticality level determination would then be used in the Acceptable Risk Model to ensure that UN personnel do not take unnecessary risk and that those who remain in-country work on highest priority activities in accordance with UN strategic results.

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: The CO supported 10 youth friendly corners with equipment to encourage the use of these corners in health facilities where young people including adolescents have access to basic health services and can also be referred if needs be. Peer educators were also trained by some of our IPs to ensure that young people have the right information to pass on to their peers to enable them make informed decisions. The CO also used the celebration of international days such as the World Population Day as an entry point to provide age appropriate and targeted information, and linkages to SRH services with the aim to reducing teenage pregnancy. The CO also supported the National Youth Authority to deploy mobile technology to facilitate transmission of youth targeted messages on sexuality education

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: With CO support, 30 implementing partners improved their knowledge on UNFPAs strategy for adolescents and youth at strategic planning meetings. The National Youth Authority has developed a manual on ASRH and related issues for their youth coordinators who work at the district level with CO support. The manual will serve as both a reference and working document for accurate ASRH information to meet the needs of marginalized youth. In addition, the CO supported the initiation of a mapping of youth- led organizations in the country. The mapping will completely document information on who is working where in relation to both youth-focused and youth-led organisations. The mapping exercise when completed, will build synergies in the delivery of ASRH and related services to young people. As a means of facilitating evidence based design and programming for marginalized and adolescent girls, the CO continued support for the conduct of a comprehensive situational analysis on young people. The CO, in partnership with government and the UN Country Team, has identified and recruited a research institution to undertake the assignment. The CO has ensured that as part of the literature review, which is the first deliverable, has reflected issues such as teenage pregnancy, unsafe abortion, early marriages and youth participation, among others

result.title: Results for UNFPA Ghana earmarked young people's sexual and reproductive health and sexuality education activities
result.description: The CO supported the National Population council to begin the process to review the current Adolescent Sexual Health Policy which was formulated in 2000 to make it more relevant to issues and priorities that have emerged since. The policy will guide strategic programming on rights based adolescent health and development issues in the country. The CO in partnership with UNICEF and UNESCO also supported the review of the HIV Alert Model and this will now reflect comprehensive life skills based sexuality education issues. The school based curriculum that incorporates age-appropriate sexuality education is being rolled out by the Curriculum Development Division of the Ghana Education Service (GES). During the period under review, the CO supported advocacy sessions conducted by the GES with district directors of education to gain support and ownership of the programme. Roll out of the use of the curriculum was also initiated in 14 out of the 30 UNFPA supported districts.
